May 14, 1989: Fiction
THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from
Bombay enact the roles of good and evil in contemporary London.
THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American
expatriate tries to thwart terrorists' attempts to prevent the signing of a
disarmament pact.
THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and bonds
shared by Chinese- American women and their immigrant mothers.
STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a
woman who are destined for stardom in different professions.
A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) A schoolboy
who accidentally killed the mother of his best friend turns into a prophet with a
message for our times.
KILLSHOT, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/ Morrow, $18.95.) Two thugs out to
assassinate a man and a woman who discovered their crime.
WE ARE STILL MARRIED, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) Stories, poems
and satirical pieces, mostly reflecting life in Minnesota.
WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$19.95.) The murder of a gossip writer creates a storm in New York's high-fashion
world.
THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$19.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through the past 5,000
centuries.
THE DIAMOND THRONE, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $18.95.) Magic,
chivalry and high adventure in a fantasy kingdom called Elenia.
BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a
28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral.
BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $19.95.) The life of the
1930's gangster Dutch Schultz, as seen by a bright youth from the Bronx.
CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A woman's visit to her
native Toronto leads her to reflect on the changes time has wrought.
THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL, by Douglas Adams. (Simon &
Schuster, $17.95.) The detective of ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy''
pursues the meaning of an explosion at an airport.
Non-Fiction
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters.
LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Observations on the
elations and frustrations of romantic relationships.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A
British scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
â€œFUNNY, YOU DON'T LOOK LIKE A GRANDMOTHER,'' by Lois Wyse. (Crown,
$12.95.) An advertising woman's reflections on her role as the grandparent of
eight.
CITIZENS, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $29.95.) A history of the French
Revolution.
OUT OF THE BLUE, by Orel Hershiser with Jerry B. Jenkins. (Wolgemuth & Hyatt,
$17.95.) The autobiography of the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher.
THE NIGHT THE BEAR ATE GOOMBAW, by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $15.95.)
Twenty-six semiautobiographical yarns by a devoted outdoorsman.
BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came
to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman.
A WOMAN NAMED JACKIE, by C. David Heymann. (Lyle Stuart, $21.95.) A
biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.
LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by
Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) An expose of tall tales that have become
part of our national heritage.
GOLDWYN, by A. Scott Berg. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the pioneering motion
picture producer.
INNUMERACY, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) Americans'
mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture.
WORDSTRUCK, by Robert MacNeil. (Viking, $18.95.) The co-host of the ''MacNeil
Lehrer Newshour'' recalls his boyhood in Canada.
ABOUT FACE, by David H. Hackworth and Julie Sherman. (Simon & Schuster,
$24.95.) A career Army officer recalls his experiences in the Korean and Vietnam
wars and in the Berlin wall and Cuban missile crises.
THE BLOODING, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $18.95.) The murder of two
teen-age girls in an English village is solved through genetic clues.
